Server APIïƒ

Development server for local testing and preview.

DisplayServerïƒ

class trelliscope.DisplayServer(display_dir, port=8000)[source]ïƒ

Bases: object

Simple HTTP server for viewing displays locally.

This server allows you to view trelliscope displays in a web browser during development. It serves static files from the display directory using Pythonâ€™s built-in HTTP server.

Parameters:

  • display_dir (Path) â€“ Path to the display directory to serve

  • port (int, optional) â€“ Port number for the server. Default: 8000

display_dirïƒ

The display directory being served

Type:

Path

portïƒ

The server port

Type:

int

httpdïƒ

The underlying HTTP server instance

Type:

socketserver.TCPServer or None

threadïƒ

Thread for non-blocking server mode

Type:

threading.Thread or None

Examples

>>> server = DisplayServer(Path("output/my_display"), port=8000)
>>> server.start(blocking=False)  # Run in background
>>> # Do other work...
>>> server.stop()  # Shutdown when done

>>> # Or run in blocking mode:
>>> server.start(blocking=True)  # Ctrl+C to stop
__init__(display_dir, port=8000)[source]ïƒ

Initialize the display server.

Parameters:

  • display_dir (Path) â€“ Path to the display directory to serve

  • port (int, optional) â€“ Port number for the server. Default: 8000

start(blocking=False)[source]ïƒ

Start the HTTP server.

Parameters:

blocking (bool, optional) â€“ If True, block until server is stopped (Ctrl+C). If False, run server in background thread. Default: False

Raises:

  • RuntimeError â€“ If server is already running

  • OSError â€“ If port is already in use

Return type:

None

Examples

>>> server = DisplayServer(Path("output/my_display"))
>>> server.start(blocking=False)  # Non-blocking
>>> print("Server running in background")
>>> server.stop()

>>> server.start(blocking=True)  # Blocking - Ctrl+C to stop
stop()[source]ïƒ

Stop the HTTP server and cleanup.

This method shuts down the server and restores the original working directory. :rtype: None

Examples

>>> server = DisplayServer(Path("output/my_display"))
>>> server.start(blocking=False)
>>> # ... do work ...
>>> server.stop()
is_running()[source]ïƒ

Check if server is currently running.

Returns:

True if server is running, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

Examples

>>> server = DisplayServer(Path("output/my_display"))
>>> server.is_running()
False
>>> server.start(blocking=False)
>>> server.is_running()
True
>>> server.stop()
>>> server.is_running()
False
get_url()[source]ïƒ

Get the server URL.

Returns:

The base URL where the server is accessible

Return type:

str

Examples

>>> server = DisplayServer(Path("output/my_display"))
>>> server.get_url()
'http://localhost:8000'
__enter__()[source]ïƒ

Context manager entry.

__exit__(exc_type, exc_val, exc_tb)[source]ïƒ

Context manager exit.

__repr__()[source]ïƒ

String representation.

Return type:

str

Examplesïƒ

Basic Serverïƒ

from trelliscope import DisplayServer

server = DisplayServer(
    display_dir="output",
    port=8000,
    host="localhost"
)

server.start()

With Display Creationïƒ

from trelliscope import Display, DisplayServer

# Create display
display = Display(df, name="example", path="output")
display.set_panel_column("plot").write()

# Serve
server = DisplayServer(display_dir="output")
server.start()

Multiple Displaysïƒ

from trelliscope import DisplayServer

# Serve directory with multiple displays
server = DisplayServer(
    display_dir="output",
    port=8000
)

server.start()
# Navigate to http://localhost:8000/

Custom Configurationïƒ

from trelliscope import DisplayServer

server = DisplayServer(
    display_dir="output",
    port=8080,
    host="0.0.0.0",  # Allow external connections
    auto_open=True    # Open browser automatically
)

server.start()

See Alsoïƒ

  • Display API - Display class

  • Export API - Static export for production
